criteria: Ability to identify claims made by fitness products.
Ability to evaluate the accuracy of the claims.
Ability to use evidence to support evaluation.
descriptions: Does not identify any claims made by fitness products.
Identifies claims without understanding their context.
Identifies claims with partial understanding.
Identifies most claims with good understanding.
Identifies all claims with clear understanding.
Identifies and explains nuances of the claims made by fitness products.
Unable to evaluate the accuracy of claims.
Attempts to evaluate claims but without reasoning.
Provides basic evaluation with flawed reasoning.
Provides adequate evaluation with some reasoning.
Provides thorough evaluation with sound reasoning.
Provides insightful evaluation with critical and nuanced reasoning, using scientific and/or expert sources.
No evidence provided to support evaluation.
Provides evidence that does not support evaluation.
Provides limited evidence with questionable relevance.
Provides evidence that supports evaluation but may be limited.
Provides sufficient evidence that clearly supports evaluation.
Provides comprehensive and compelling evidence from credible sources to support evaluation.
Evaluation is unclear and disorganized.
Evaluation is difficult to follow with little organization.
Evaluation is somewhat clear but lacks logical organization.
Evaluation is clear and organized logically.
Evaluation is very clear, well-organized, and easy to follow.
Evaluation is exceptionally clear, logically structured, and demonstrates sophisticated communication skills.
